com.apw.apw3

Class HandyOps

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apw.apw3.HandyOps

  • public class HandyOps
extends java.lang.Object
    Handy Operations that should be simple (but maybe aren't so in Java)..

      • IffyStr

        public static java.lang.String IffyStr(boolean whom,
                                       java.lang.String tru,
                                       java.lang.String fls)
        Strongly-typed (not overloaded) string selector. This is part of a collection of tools for building debug print lines.
        Parameters:
        whom - The selector
        tru - Returned if whom=true
        fls - Returned if whom=false
        Returns:
        The selected string, tru if whom=true, else fls

      • TF2Log

        public static java.lang.String TF2Log(java.lang.String before,
                                      boolean whom,
                                      java.lang.String after)
        Formats a boolean (as "T" or "F") and returns it with a prefix and suffix. This is one of several similar tools for building debug print lines.
        Parameters:
        before - The prefix
        whom - The boolean value to be formatted
        after - The suffix
        Returns:
        The combined string

      • Dec2Log

        public static java.lang.String Dec2Log(java.lang.String before,
                                       int whom,
                                       java.lang.String after)
        Formats an integer and returns it with a prefix and suffix. This is one of several similar tools for building debug print lines.
        Parameters:
        before - The prefix
        whom - The number to be formatted
        after - The suffix
        Returns:
        The combined string

      • Hex2Log

        public static java.lang.String Hex2Log(java.lang.String before,
                                       int whom,
                                       int nx,
                                       java.lang.String after)
        Formats an integer as hexadecimal and returns it with a prefix and suffix. This is one of several similar tools for building debug print lines.
        Parameters:
        before - The prefix
        whom - The number to be formatted
        nx - The number of digits to be formatted (excess bits ignored)
        after - The suffix
        Returns:
        The combined string

      • Int2Log

        public static java.lang.String Int2Log(java.lang.String before,
                                       int whom,
                                       java.lang.String after)
        Formats an integer according to its likely value and returns it with a prefix and suffix. If it appears to be two 16-bit integers packed into one 32-bit number, the two parts are returned separated by a comma. Very large numbers (more than signed 15 bits) are returned as hexadecimal.

        This is one of several similar tools for building debug print lines.

        Parameters:
        before - The prefix
        whom - The number to be formatted
        after - The suffix
        Returns:
        The combined string

      • Colo2Log

        public static java.lang.String Colo2Log(java.lang.String before,
                                        int whom,
                                        java.lang.String after)
        Formats an integer representation of a color and returns it as a 3-digit RGB (each as 4-bit hex) with a prefix and suffix.

        This is one of several similar tools for building debug print lines.

        Parameters:
        before - The prefix
        whom - The number to be formatted
        after - The suffix
        Returns:
        The combined string

      • Flt2Log

        public static java.lang.String Flt2Log(java.lang.String before,
                                       double whom,
                                       java.lang.String after)
        Formats a floating-point number and returns it with a prefix and suffix. If there is no fractional part, no digits are shown after the decimal point; otherwise a single (rounded) fractional digit is shown.

        This is one of several similar tools for building debug print lines.

        Parameters:
        before - The prefix
        whom - The number to be formatted
        after - The suffix
        Returns:
        The combined string

      • PosTime

        public static java.lang.String PosTime(java.lang.String before)
        Formats the time since TrakSim started as mm:ss:ms and returns it with a prefix. It is normally added to the end of the debug line for a visual way to see where processing time is being spent.

        This is one of several similar tools for building debug print lines.

        Parameters:
        before - The prefix
        Returns:
        The combined string

      • CharAt

        public static char CharAt(int here,
                          java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) non-OOPS way to extract a character from a string.
        Parameters:
        here - The (0-base) character position
        aStr - The string from which to extract that character
        Returns:
        The character extracted, or '\0' if out of bounds

      • TimeSecs

        public static int TimeSecs(boolean ms2)
        Returns the time since TrakSim started, as integer seconds.
        Parameters:
        ms2 - True: returns milliseconds instead of seconds
        Returns:
        The time

      • SafeParseInt

        public static int SafeParseInt(java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to extract an integer number from a string. If the number begins with "0x" then it is assumed to be hexadecimal. Leading white space is ignored, and the first character that is not part of the number ends the scan.
        Parameters:
        aStr - The string from which to extract that character
        Returns:
        The number parsed, or 0 if none

      • Countem

        public static int Countem(java.lang.String aWord,
                          java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to count the number of (non-overlapping) occurrences of a particular string within a larger string. An empty string cannot be counted.
        Parameters:
        aWord - The string to look for
        aStr - The string in which to find and count it
        Returns:
        The number of occurrences found, or 0 if none

      • NthOffset

        public static int NthOffset(int whom,
                            java.lang.String aWord,
                            java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to find the (0-based) offset of a particular string within a larger string, while ignoring zero or more initial (non-overlapping) occurrences. An empty string cannot be found.
        Parameters:
        whom - The number of occurrences to skip over
        aWord - The string to look for
        aStr - The string in which to find it
        Returns:
        The (indexOf) offset, or -1 if not found

      • NthItemOf

        public static java.lang.String NthItemOf(boolean lino,
                                         int whom,
                                         java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to extract a word or line from a string. When getting words, excess white space is ignored, so the returned string is empty only when asking for a word beyond the end. Consecutive \n line breaks result in empty lines being returned, so that you always get the nth line of a multi-line string. Words or lines past the end or before the front (0 or less) are empty.
        Parameters:
        lino - True to get a whole line, false to get a word
        whom - The (1-base) line or word number to get
        aStr - The string from which to extract that word or line
        Returns:
        The number parsed, or 0 if none

      • SafeParseFlt

        public static double SafeParseFlt(java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to extract an floating-point number from a string. Leading white space is ignored, and the first character that is not part of the number ends the scan.
        Parameters:
        aStr - The string from which to extract that character
        Returns:
        The number parsed, or 0.0 if none

      • RepNthLine

        public static java.lang.String RepNthLine(java.lang.String aLine,
                                          int whom,
                                          java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to replace a single line with one or more new lines. A zero or negative line number is the same as no original.
        Parameters:
        aLine - The original string in which to replace the line
        whom - The (1-base) line or word number to replace
        aStr - The string to replace that line with
        Returns:
        The number parsed, or 0 if none

      • RestOf

        public static java.lang.String RestOf(int here,
                                      java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to get the rest of a string. Text past the end is considered empty.
        Parameters:
        here - The (0-base) position to start
        aStr - The string from which to extract that substring
        Returns:
        The rest of the string, after whom

      • Substring

        public static java.lang.String Substring(int here,
                                         int lxx,
                                         java.lang.String aStr)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to extract a substring. Text past the end is empty.
        Parameters:
        here - The (0-base) position to start
        lxx - The desired length (the result could be less)
        aStr - The string from which to extract that substring
        Returns:
        The substring

      • ReplacAll

        public static java.lang.String ReplacAll(java.lang.String aStr,
                                         java.lang.String xStr,
                                         java.lang.String whom)
        A safe (no exceptions) way to replace every instance of a particular string in a larger text with another string. An empty string cannot be replaced. Only original instances are replaced; if replacement results in additional instances of the sought string, the new instances will not be replaced.
        Parameters:
        aStr - The new string to replace it
        xStr - The string to find and be replaced
        whom - The original string in which to find and replace
        Returns:
        The updated string whom, after all replacements

      • ArrayDumpLine

        public static java.lang.String ArrayDumpLine(int[] theAry,
                                             int nw,
                                             int pos)
        A safe way to format part of all of an integer array as a text string of integers. The result string is divided into lines so that no line is longer than 80; it is assumed that this will be attached to text of a specified length from another source, which will be considered in folding the first line.
        Parameters:
        theAry - The array to be formatted
        nw - The maximum number of words to format, or all if 0
        pos - The assumed length of its prefix; if pos<0 then it will stop after the first 0 value encountered
        Returns:
        The formatted string

      • ReadWholeTextFile

        public static java.lang.String ReadWholeTextFile(java.lang.String filename)
        A safe way to read a whole text file. The result string is divided into lines so that no line is longer than 80; it is assumed that this will be attached to text of a specified length from another source, which will be considered in folding the first line.
        Parameters:
        filename - The name of the text file
        Returns:
        The text as read

      • Int4bytes

        public static int Int4bytes(boolean LiLEfi,
                            byte by0,
                            byte by1,
                            byte by2,
                            byte by3)
        Packs 4 bytes into an integer with due respect to Endian-ness.
        Parameters:
        LiLEfi - True if the data is Little-Endian, false if Big-End
        by0 - First data byte
        by1 - Secong data byte
        by2 - Third data byte
        by3 - Fourth data byte
        Returns:
        The reconstructed integer

      • ReadTiff32Image

        public static int ReadTiff32Image(java.lang.String filename,
                                  int[] pixels)
        A simple way to read the pixels from a Tiff32 file. Call it twice, first with null to get the size of the image, then with an array big enough to hold as many of those pixels as you want. It may fail if you don't call it the first time.
        Parameters:
        filename - The name of the Tiff file
        pixels - An array to put the pixels into, or null to get only the dimensions
        Returns:
        The height*0x10000+width, or zero if error

      • Fixt8th

        public static java.lang.String Fixt8th(java.lang.String before,
                                       int whom,
                                       java.lang.String after)
        Formats a fixed.point integer with three bits of fraction and returns it as a precise decimal number with a prefix and suffix. Similar to Flt2Log.
        Parameters:
        before - The prefix
        whom - The number to be formatted
        after - The suffix
        Returns:
        The combined string
